body: Heap dump can be found here : https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B4oLBHnhTfE3M0JDbjhJWXVJZ3c/view?usp=sharing

I'm seeing this as well, I'm not sharing content but I am using PackageManager to query activities.

```
        LeakCanary  D  In com.teslacoilsw.launcher:#materinova.30:39030.
                    D  * com.android.launcher3.LauncherWallpaperPickerActivity has leaked:
                    D  * GC ROOT static android.os.UserManager.sInstance
                    D  * references android.os.UserManager.mContext
                    D  * references android.app.ContextImpl.mOuterContext
                    D  * leaks com.android.launcher3.LauncherWallpaperPickerActivity instance
                    D  * Reference Key: 0ffc805f-0c52-4213-9ac9-a09a033f0d9b
                    D  * Device: motorola google Nexus 6 shamu
                    D  * Android Version: 5.1 API: 22
                    D  * Durations: watch=5030ms, gc=213ms, heap dump=1840ms, analysis=17527ms
```

In my case, an easy work around is to use getApplicationContext().getPackageManager() rather than getPackageManager directly from the activity.

repository.name: leakcanary
repository.description: A memory leak detection library for Android.

body: The fix for app developers says that `UserManager.get()` should be called, but this function doesn't seem to exist [[1]](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/UserManager.html)

You can use reflection, or attempt to trigger a call through other means. For example on Lollipop:

```
app.getPackageManager().getUserBadgedLabel("", android.os.Process.myUserHandle());
```

Will trigger a call to UserManager.get(app) and do little else.

I imagine there is a similar method that would work on Jellybean and kitkat, but I haven't looked.
Yep, when it comes to this sorts of hacks, you need to look at the source, not the doc.

issue.title: Leak in android.os.UserManager (API: 21)

repository.name: leakcanary
repository.description: A memory leak detection library for Android.

issue.body:
This seems like a recurrence of Issue #62 

Like issue #62, it occurred when coming back from a share intent. I thought the fix (5df8cbb) for #62 ignored this leak but perhaps it's been fixed in AOSP and then it's an issue with this manufacturer (HTC).

```
* com.myapp.android.TasksFragment has leaked:
* GC ROOT static android.os.UserManager.sInstance
* references android.os.UserManager.mContext
* references android.app.ContextImpl.mOuterContext
* references com.myapp.android.ContentShareActivity.mFragments
* references android.app.FragmentManagerImpl.mAdded
* references java.util.ArrayList.array
* references array java.lang.Object[].[1]
* leaks com.myapp.android.TasksFragment instance

* Reference Key: a2eba689-7036-4194-ba33-e6a0f19277d8
* Device: HTC htc HTC One orange_uk
* Android Version: 5.0.2 API: 21 LeakCanary: 1.3.1
* Durations: watch=5127ms, gc=191ms, heap dump=3026ms, analysis=48242ms
```

`TasksFragment` above is a retained Fragment which holds a couple of AsyncTasks neither of which hold any references to Activity context

body:
This leak seems to still exist in 6.0.x (on my Sony Xperia Z3), as well as user reports on the Google bug ticket https://code.google.com/p/android/issues/detail?id=173789

Can the `SDK_INT` upper bound be increased in `AndroidExcludedRefs.java`?
